question: The following is an image of a paleontological fossil, please provide a detailed description for the fossil image. Here is some information about the fossil:length: 10.802 mm. , width(diameter): 3.179 mm. ratio: 3.398number of volutions(whorls): 6.5thickness of spirotheca: 0.035height of volution/whorl: 0.157 mm the 1st volution, 0.170 mm the 2nd volution, 0.185 mm the 3rd volution, 0.272 mm the 4th volution, 0.285 mm the 5th volution, 0.292 mm the 6th volution.initial chamber(proloculus): 219μtunnel angles: 20 degrees in the 2nd volution, 24 degrees in the 5th volution.
output: The shell is characterized by a fusiform shape with concave slopes and rounded ends. Its dimensions are as follows: axial length is 10.802 mm, sagittal width is 3.179 mm, and the ratio of length to width is approximately 3.398. The shell's axis is straight. The shell exhibits 6.5 volutions, with the inner volutions being narrower. The thickness of the spirotheca is 0.035 mm. The height of each volution, measured from the first to the sixth, is 0.157 mm, 0.170 mm, 0.185 mm, 0.272 mm, 0.285 mm, and 0.292 mm, respectively. The proloculus is small and spherical, with a diameter of 219 μm. The tunnels are relatively low and narrow. The angles of the second and fifth volutions are 20° and 24°, respectively. The chomata are well-developed and small in size.
reference: Test large, rhomboid in outline, concave in middle on one side and convex on another side; median axis sinuous, and extremities sharp. Volutions 6.5; inner 4-5 volutions tightly involute and successive ones loosening gradually. Holotype specimen 10.802 mm long, 3.179 mm wide, and 3.398 in axial ratio. Spirotheca very thin in tightly coiled inner volutions, about 0.035 mm thick; thickening outwards; composed of a tectum and a keriotheca; the spirotheca on the sixth volution about 0.07 mm thick. Septa are plane and straight in the inner volutions, and completely fluted in the outer volutions; flutings broadly rounded in general, sometimes reaching the top of the chambers in height. Chomata small, only visible in the inner volutions. Tunnels low, moderately wide. Axial fillings heavy, distributed on the lateral sides of median axis, except the final volution. Proloculus circular, its outside diameter varying from 219μ. Tunnel angles measuring 20 degrees in the 2nd volution and 24 degrees in the 5th volution.

reference: Fusulinide di dimensioni piuttosto grandi con la massima lunghezza (L) di 11.836 mm al IX-X giro di spira. Forma a fuso rigonfio al centro, con zone polari molto sporgenti, ma non affilate. Parete keriotecale, costituita dal tectum e da una kerioteca piuttosto sottile. Proloculus di piccole dimensioni, con un diametro esterno di 329μ. La spira è strettamente avvolta nei primi 4 giri e si allarga decisamente nei giri successivi.Setti non piegati nel primo giro; poco piegati, con pieghe basse, nel II e III-IV giro. Setti molto piegati a partire dal V giro, con pieghe alte, fino a raggiungere il soffitto delle logge, e strette a 'V.' Nelle sezioni assiali si nota una netta 'fascia assiale cellulare.' Chomata assenti; pseudochomata presenti nei giri più interni. Riempimenti assiali lineari, osservabili dal II al V giro soltanto. Tunnel visibile solo nei primi 5 giri, con angoli di tunnel misurati 9 gradi nel II giro, 26 gradi nel III giro, 11 gradi nel IV giro, 21 gradi nel V giro, e 30 gradi nel VI giro. Numero dei giri di spira: 6.5.La 'forma ratio' (R) cresce molto rapidamente nei primi giri e raggiunge al IV giro valori superiori a 4 (Fig. 2); essa decresce successivamente e si stabilizza dal VII giro in poi attorno a valori compresi fra 2.0 e 3.0. Il conteggio dei setti in ogni giro della spira, nell'unico esemplare che abbia sezione diametrale nel seguente: VI giro - 24 setti; VII giro - 29 setti; VIII giro - 33 setti; IX giro - 40 setti circa.

reference: Shell moderate in size and slender fusiform, with almost straight axis of coiling, flat to very gently convex lateral slopes, and sharply pointed poles. The holotype specimen of 2.0 volutions measures 5.621 mm in length and 1.452 mm in width, giving a form ratio of 3.871. The innermost volution short fusiform, and from the second volution axis extends very rapidly. Rate of extension of axis becomes less rapid in outer two or three volutions in some specimens including the holotype. [Average] ratios of half length to radius vector of the first to sixth volutions, in four specimens 2.27, 3.23, 3.88, 3.78, 3.83, and 3.98, respectively. Proloculus small and subspherical, with outside diameter of 88 microns. Wall of proloculus 9 to 12 microns. Shell very tightly coils in inner three volutions, and thereafter moderately and almost uniformly in outer volutions. Average radius vectors of the first to sixth volutions in four specimens 92, 123, 177, 258, 391, and 565 microns, respectively. Chambers almost the same in height except for polar areas where they slightly increase in height. Spirotheca thin and consists of a tectum and a finely alveolar keriotheca. About 5 alveoli are observed in a distance of 100 microns of keriotheca of outer volutions. Thickness of spirotheca of the first to sixth volutions in three specimens averages 0.012 mm. Septa thin and the same in structure as spirotheca. Septa plane in inner three to four volutions, and weakly fluted in polar areas of succeeding one or two volutions. In the last one or two volutions septal fluting reaches tops of chamber in polar areas, but is limited to the lower portion of septa in median portion, where chamberlets formed by septal flutings are about a half to two-thirds as high as chambers. Chomata developed in outer volutions except the last one, being low and asymmetrical with steep tunnel sides and gentle poleward slopes. Tunnel low and broad with nearly straight tunnel path. Tunnel angles of the third to seventh volutions in the holotype specimen measured 44°, 50°, 52°, 50º, and 54°, respectively. Secondary deposits occur in very narrow Zone along axis almost throughout growth.

reference: Test reaching a fairly large size for species of this genus, sub-spherical with distinctly elongated poles, walls in volutions of the neanic stage closely wound. They become shorter, stouter, and more closely spaced in the gerontic stage. They are nearly straight in the last two growth stages, except in the axial zone which is well developed. reference: Shell thickly fusiform with bluntly pointed poles, consisting of 6.5 volutions. Observed half length ranges from 0.330 mm in the first volution to 0.444 mm in the sixth volution; observed radius vector ranges from 0.334 mm in the second volution to 0.216 mm in the fourth volution. Form ratio of observed values ranges from 1.7 to 2.1 in the fifth and sixth volutions. The formula for the arithmetic linear regression is: y=.01 +.49x (see tf. 36).Proloculi are moderately large and spherical; observed range of outside diameter is from 109 μm to 340 μm. The proloculus wall is thick. Its thickness is approximately that of the second volution, and has an observed range from 30 to 40 microns.The juvenarium includes two and one-half volutions in nearly all specimens. The whorls are closely coiled in the juvenarium, after which the acceleration of expansion increases suddenly. The rate of expansion is not constant, and the final whorl frequently is lower than the penultimate volution.The spirotheca is finely alveolar. It is thin in the early volutions but reaches an observed range of thickness from 95 to 125 microns in fifth and sixth volutions.Septa are strongly folded; the folds are unusually regular for a species of Pseudoschwagerina. Low septal loops are developed throughout the length of the septum except immediately above the tunnel in the juvenarium. Septal pores are fine and rather closely spaced.The tunnel is high and narrow in the juvenarium. It is difficult to trace in later volutions, but appears to be continuous in a straight path in all volutions. Tunnel angles measure 20 degrees in the second volution, 16 degrees in the third volution, 14 degrees in the fourth volution, 9 degrees in the fifth volution, and 8 degrees in the sixth volution. Relatively massive chomata bound the tunnel in the juvenarium, but are entirely lacking in later volutions.

Number of whorls usually 6.5."Spirotheca thin in the inner volutions but rather thick in the outer whorls, being 0.066 mm. in the fourth volution and 0.11 mm. in the fifth. The alveolar structure of the keriotheca cannot be distinctly observed; this is mainly due to poor preservation. The spirotheca is not uniform in thickness and appears gently undulating, although rather thick."Antithecae almost unfluted over a wide area in the median portion; only simple folding occurs in the lateral parts, being restricted to the lower margin of antithecae and confined to a limited area. Number of antithecae in the successive volutions: approximately ten in the first volution, twenty-one in the second, twenty-four in the third, and twenty-six in the fourth."Widths of the successive volutions: table omitted"Chomata rather strongly developed in the inner two or three whorls, generally obsolete in the outer volutions, but sometimes continuing with faint traces up to the last whorl. Buccal aperture low and narrow, occupying 1/13 of the length of the respective whorls. Initial chamber spherical, thick-walled, with a diameter of 0.32 mm."Tunnel low and rather narrow, tunnel angle measuring 30 degrees in the 1st volution, 35 degrees in the 2nd volution, 50 degrees in the 3rd volution, 36 degrees in the 4th volution, 22 degrees in the 5th volution, 16 degrees in the 6th volution, 24 degrees in the 7th volution, 11 degrees in the 8th volution.

question: The following is an image of a paleontological fossil, please provide a detailed description for the fossil image. output: The shell is characterized by an ellipsoidal shape with elongated slopes and rounded ends. Its dimensions are as follows: the axial length measures 8.118 mm, while the sagittal width is 3.982 mm, resulting in a length-to-width ratio of 2.039. The shell's axis is straight. The shell exhibits 6.0 volutions, with the tunnels being relatively low and narrow. The thickness of the spirotheca is 0.078 mm. The heights of the first to fifth volutions are 0.158 mm, 0.198 mm, 0.303 mm, 0.410 mm, and 0.577 mm, respectively. The proloculus is small and spherical, with a diameter of 286 μm. The tunnel angles of the first to fifth volutions are 11°, 29°, 17°, 22°, and 14°, respectively. The chomata are well-developed and small in size.
reference: The shell of Pseudoschwagerina convexa is large, with extended, bluntly pointed to rounded poles, inflated center, and almost straight axis of coiling. It has sharply pointed poles in the inner three volutions, but from the fourth volution outward the poles become slightly extended and bluntly pointed to rounded. In the fourth and fifth volutions of some specimens the lateral slopes are slightly concave. Mature specimens contain six volutions and are 8.118 mm long and 3.982 mm wide. The holotype specimen is composed of six volutions and is 9.6 mm long and 4.8 mm wide. The average form ratio of three mature specimens is 2.1. The form ratio of the holotype is 2.0. The average form ratios of the first to sixth volution in four specimens are 1.4, 1.7, 2.0, 2.1, 2.1, and 2.0, respectively. As these figures indicate, the form ratio increases about uniformly for the first three to four volutions but increases only slightly, if at all, in the outer three volutions.The proloculus is large, with an outside diameter of 286 microns. Its thickness in five specimens ranges from 26 to 41 microns, averaging 34 microns. The expansion of the shell is about uniform during the first three volutions; during the fourth volution the height of the chambers increases rapidly, and from there to maturity the chambers decrease in height slowly. The outermost volution of mature specimens is relatively tightly coiled. The height of the first to sixth volution in five specimens averages 116, 188, 244, 404, 564, and 533 microns, respectively. The height of the first to sixth volution in the holotype is 100, 160, 240, 260, 600, and 580 microns, respectively.The spirotheca is relatively thick for the genus, but it changes in thickness with growth of the individual approximately in the same manner as in the genotype, Pseudoschwagerina uddeni (Beede and Kniker) [Schwagerina uddeni, 1924] and other congeneric species. The thickness of the spirotheca in the first to sixth volution in five specimens averages 27, 38, 54, 75, 97, and 105 microns, respectively. The spirotheca of the first to sixth volution in the holotype increases 68, 86, 104, and 90 microns, respectively. Thus the spirotheca increases in thickness slowly with growth of the individual for the first four volutions, beyond which it increases in thickness rapidly but decreases in the outermost volution of mature specimens. The alveoli of the keriotheca are coarse but are poorly preserved in many parts of the holotype and in the paratypes. The proloculus wall is thick, averaging about 34 microns in five specimens.The septa are closely spaced in the inner four to five volutions, more widely spaced in the following two volutions. They are narrowly and highly fluted throughout the length of the shell. The folds of the septa are not uniform vertically, however, for axial sections may intersect the same fold at two points. The septa are thick in the area of the tunnel and are thin in the polar region.The tunnel is broad and relatively high in the second and third before the last volution. Chomata are broad and high in the inner four volutions but low and discontinuous in outer volutions. The absence of distinct chomata makes it difficult to measure accurately the tunnel angle in the outer volutions, and measurements given in Table 10 for angles of these volutions are only close approximations. The average tunnel angles of the first to sixth volution of four specimens are about 11, 29, 17, 22, 14, and 29 degrees, respectively.

The shell exhibits 5.5 volutions, with the inner volutions featuring narrow tunnels. The thickness of the spirotheca is 0.044 mm. The heights of the first to fifth volutions are 0.186, 0.254, 0.446, 0.372, and 0.241 mm, respectively. The proloculus is small and spherical, with a diameter of 132 μm. reference: A slender species for this genus with bluntly rounded poles and without an equatorial bulge, the axial profile being an elongate ellipse with a form ratio of 2.305. The shell has 5.5 volutions and reaches a length of 7.810 mm and a diameter of 3.388 mm.The prolocula ranges from 132 μm in diameter. The juvenarium includes from 1-1/2 to 3-1/2 volutions, the number varying inversely with the size of the proloculum. Accordingly, the statistical measurements as tabulated below appear rather widely discordant since the second or third volution in one shell may represent the tightly coiled juvenarium and in another the inflated part of the shell. For example, specimen no. 1 with a smaller proloculum and five volutions corresponds very closely in adult size and shape with specimen no. 4 which has a larger proloculum and only four volutions.In the juvenarium, there are well-defined but slender chomata that disappear in the first of the inflated whorls. The inflation is not quite so rapid as in P. kozlowskii Dunbar and Newell, the whorls do not reach so great a height, and the poles are more bluntly rounded.The spiral wall is like that of P. kozlowskii in structure and thickness.The septa are widely spaced, as is usual in this genus, and are gently folded so that in axial sections the septal loops appear sparse and very irregular. There is a tendency for the lower margin of the septa to be more deeply folded in the outer whorl. The final volution commonly decreases in height, as shown in figs. 8 and 9, and the septa are more closely spaced. In some shells, these last chambers show a rather close tangle of septal loops. Septal pores are abundant in the inflated whorls.The tunnel is rather wide, increasing from 16 degrees in the first volution to 23 degrees in the second volution, 14 degrees in the third volution, 52 degrees in the fourth volution, and 9 degrees in the fifth volution. It is clearly defined by the thechomata in the juvenile whorls but is commonly not well shown in good thin sections of the outer whorls where it can be studied best in thick sections of polished surfaces.

Outer one or one and one-half volutions of mature shells have somewhat lower chambers and somewhat more closely spaced septa than those of fourth and fifth volutions. Chambers of about the same height throughout the length of the shell. Height of first to sixth volutions of holotype about 79μ, 193μ, 287μ, 700μ, 1048μ, and 443μ, respectively. Septa closely spaced in inner volutions, widely spaced in fourth and fifth volutions, and somewhat more closely spaced in outer volutions. Septa fluted throughout the length of the shell, but fluting seems to be irregularly developed, probably due largely to irregular attitude of septa. In general, septa tend to curve anteriorly. Most of them are irregular in vertical sections. Many septa are strongly sinuous in vertical sections, fluting forms closed chamberlets in the lower half to fourth of chambers, tangential sections reveal transverse paths connecting adjacent chambers, as are found in Parafusulina. Cuneoli have not been previously reported in pseudoschwagerina. It should, however, be stressed that published tangential sections of Pseudoschwagerina are indeed rare, and the presence or absence of cuneoli in most previously described forms of the genus cannot be verified from available information. A restudy of the original or topotype material of previously described forms may demonstrate that cuneoli are common rather than rare in pseudoschwagerina. The presence of cuneoli in p. dallmusi may indicate that this form is highly advanced. Septal pores exceedingly abundant throughout the shell but most easily observed in outer volutions. output: The shell is characterized by a sub-ellipsoidal shape with elongated slopes and rounded ends. Its dimensions are as follows: the axial length measures 7.689 mm, while the sagittal width is 2.596 mm, resulting in a length-to-width ratio of 2.962. The shell's axis is straight. The shell exhibits 4.5 volutions, with the inner volutions being narrower. The thickness of the spirotheca is 0.043 mm. The heights of the first to fourth volutions are 0.210 mm, 0.231 mm, 0.330 mm, and 0.312 mm, respectively. The proloculus is small and spherical, with a diameter of 219 μm. reference: The shell is of medium size. In profile it varies from subglobular, to inflated fusiform with bluntly pointed poles, to subcylindrical with bluntly rounded poles and gently convex lateral slopes. The holotype (pl. 7, fig. 6) is 7.689 mm. long and 2.596 mm. wide. Eight mature specimens including the holotype vary from 5.3 to 8 mm. in length and 1.7 to 2.6 mm. in width, giving form ratios of 2.2 to 3.4. The poles of the first one or two volutions are commonly pointed whereas those of succeeding volutions are bluntly rounded. Average form ratios of the first to the fifth volutions in eight specimens are 1.8, 1.9, 2.3, 2.8, and 2.9. The proloculus varies considerably in outside diameter among different specimens, measurements range between 189 to 462 microns and the average for twelve specimens was 219 microns. The proloculus is generally round to subround but in a few specimens it was highly irregular (pl. 7, fig. 5). Average heights of the chambers in the first to fifth volution in twelve specimens are 104, 163, 229, 273, and 273 microns. The height of the chambers is generally lowest over the tunnel and expands in the direction of the poles. The spirotheca is moderately thick with a well-defined tectum and keriotheca that is coarsely alveolar. Average thicknesses of the spirotheca in the first to the fifth volution in ten specimens are 30, 42, 57, 74, and 67 microns. The thickness of the spirotheca in the first volution is 0.043.The septa are narrowly fluted to their tops across the axial region of the shell but appear to be much more intense and irregular in the end thirds of the shell. Cuniculi were observed in only one specimen assigned to this species (pl. 8, fig. 8). The septal counts of the first to the fifth volution in four specimens are 12, 22, 23, 25, and 24.The tunnel is somewhat irregular, especially in the innermost chambers. It is narrow in the inner parts of the shell but widens rapidly in the outer volutions. Chomata with steep to overhanging tunnel slopes and steep poleward slopes are conspicuous in the inner two or three chambers where these deposits extend to about one half the height of the chambers. In the outer volution they are irregular deposits on the septa that extend to the tops of the chambers and laterally along the side of the septa. Average tunnel angles in the first to the fourth volution of eight specimens are 16 degrees in the 1st volution, 11 degrees in the 2nd volution, and 17 degrees in the 3rd volution.

output: The shell is characterized by an ellipsoidal shape with elongated slopes and rounded ends. Its dimensions are as follows: the axial length measures 6.281 mm, while the sagittal width is 3.311 mm, resulting in a length-to-width ratio of 1.897. The shell's axis is straight. The shell exhibits 7.0 volutions, with the inner volutions featuring narrow tunnels. The thickness of the spirotheca is 0.053 mm. The heights of the first to seventh volutions are 0.140 mm, 0.195 mm, 0.283 mm, 0.224 mm, 0.326 mm, 0.189 mm, and 0.332 mm, respectively. The proloculus is small and spherical, with a diameter of 219 μm. The tunnel angles of the second to eighth volutions are 17°, 12°, 33°, 16°, 19°, and 9°, respectively. reference: A thickly fusiform species with evenly elliptical axial profile and subacutely pointed poles. It commonly has 7.0 volutions and attains a length of 6.281 mm and a diameter of 3.311 mm, the form ratio varying from 1.897. The proloculum shows a considerable range in size, being only 140 microns in diameter in measured specimen no. 5 but 230 microns in specimen no. 6 and 400 microns in another specimen, but it is commonly between 175 and 250 microns in diameter and is subspherical.The juvenarium commonly includes about 2-1/2 volutions but if the proloculum is small it may amount to 3-1/2 volutions and if the proloculum is large the juvenarium may be reduced to two volutions. In this portion of the shell the whorls are low and the tunnel is bordered by rather slender but well-defined chomata.Following the juvenarium the whorl rapidly increases in height, commonly reaching a maximum within half a volution and then declining again in the last whorl as well shown in figs. 6 and 7. Chomata are usually completely lacking in the inflated whorls.The spiral wall is alveolar, showing well-defined tectum and keriotheca and increasing gradually in thickness from 20 to 30 microns in the first whorl to about so microns in the third and commonly near 100 microns in the fifth.The septa are gently folded but since they are widely spaced in the inflated whorls the septal loops appear sparse and extremely irregular in axial sections. The true extent of folding is better shown in the juvenile whorls where the septa are more closely spaced and invariably lie near the plane of the section. As shown in fig. 7, the septa appear short and thick in the juvenile whorls and very long and much thinner in the inflated whorls. Septal pores are abundant in the inflated whorls.The tunnel is rather narrow in the juvenile whorls where it is bounded by narrow chomata; but in the inflated whorls it can seldom be measured in thin sections because the septa are so spaced that only rarely does one coincide with the slice. Commonly the septal folds increase in depth in the outer volution. Tunnel angles measure 17 degrees in the 2nd volution, 12 degrees in the 3rd volution, 33 degrees in the 4th volution, 16 degrees in the 5th volution, and 19 degrees in the 7th volution.

reference: Mittelgross, spindelförmig, spitze oder leicht gerundete Pole, Lange 5.449 mm.; Breite 2.457 mm.; Länge/Breite 2.218; vier Windungen, ungleichmassige Aufrollung, zwei Jugendwindungen, rascher Ubergang zur Reife. The first two or three whorls are closely coiled; then the coiling rapidly becomes broader. In the last volution, the whorl is again closer as compared with the preceding one. Thus, the three stages of growth—young, adult, and senile—are clearly observable in the axial and median sections as well as in the width graphs by the change of the gradient of the curves.Spirotheca initially very thin; alveolar structure of the osseum hardly observable; but in later development, it steadily grows thicker; at the same time, the osseum becomes coarser. In the thickest part, which usually occurs in the last but one volution, its thickness is often no less than 0.032 mm.Antithecae short and relatively thin in the young, long and thin in the adult, and short and thick in the senile stage. They are gently fluted as a whole, but more intensely folded along the lower edge. Only in the very umbilical ends the loops and anastomosis usually observed in Schellwienia Staff and Wedenkind begin to make their appearance.Annuli very small and rudimentary in the first two or three volutions, disappearing from the third volution onward. Buccal aperture small and narrow in the inner volutions, becoming broader and larger but ill-defined in the outer ones. Initial chamber very small, spherical, having a diameter of 58 μm. Tunnel low and rather narrow, tunnel angle measuring 20 degrees in the 1st volution, 5 degrees in the 2nd volution, 12 degrees in the 3rd volution, and 5 degrees in the 4th volution.

output: The shell is characterized by a fusiform shape with concave slopes and rounded ends. Its dimensions are as follows: axial length is 5.544 mm, sagittal width is 3.828 mm, and the ratio of length to width is 1.448. The shell's axis is straight. The shell exhibits 6.5 volutions, with the inner volutions being narrower. The thickness of the spirotheca is 0.115 mm. The height of each volution, measured from the first to the sixth, is 0.225 mm, 0.437 mm, 0.310 mm, 0.207 mm, 0.238 mm, and 0.289 mm, respectively. The proloculus is small and spherical, with a diameter of 132 μm. The tunnels are low and narrow. The angles of the tunnels in the second to seventh volutions are 7°, 17°, 10°, 23°, 7°, and 14°, respectively.
reference: Test strongly inflated, with sharply convex sides and broadly rounded axial ends. The shape of the test varies little from whorl to whorl. Ratio of length to diameter in juvenile stage 1.65-1.80:1; in the adult stage, 1.448:1. Dimensions small: length 5.544 mm.; diameter 3.828 mm. Number of whorls 6.5, Initial chamber rather large, 132μ in diameter. Spiral tightly coiled in the first three or four whorls of the juvenile stage, more broadly coiled in the following whorls, reaching the maximum height (0.52-0.57 mm) along one to one and one-half whorls. Height of whorls in holotype (in mm.): First 0.225; second 0.437; third 0.310; fourth 0.207; fifth 0.238; sixth 0.289. The wall, which gradually becomes thicker, does not show the thinning at the beginning of the adult stage which is characteristic of the genus Pseudoschwagerina. Thickness of wall in holotype, by whorls (in μ): First 25; second 35; third 60; fourth 65; fifth 100; and sixth 130. The thickness of the wall in specimens from subsurface massifs is greater than of those from other strata. In the median region of the whorls of the juvenile stage there is a well-expressed outer tectorium. Septa of moderate thickness, slightly thickened in the median region, irregularly and relatively strongly folded in the lower part. The folding in the adult and senile stages is stronger than in the juvenile stages. Aperture of moderate width, gradually broadening toward the outside. Chomata very distinct in the whorls of the juvenile stage, weak, but almost always noticeable in the following ones. Tunnel low and rather narrow, tunnel angle measuring 7 degrees in the 2nd volution, 17 degrees in the 3rd volution, 10 degrees in the 4th volution, 23 degrees in the 5th volution, 7 degrees in the 6th volution, and 14 degrees in the 7th volution.

question: The following is an image of a paleontological fossil, please provide a detailed description for the fossil image. Here is some information about the fossil:length: 6.611 mm. , width(diameter): 3.388 mm. ratio: 1.951number of volutions(whorls): 6.0thickness of spirotheca: 0.086height of volution/whorl: 0.142 mm the 1st volution, 0.190 mm the 2nd volution, 0.258 mm the 3rd volution, 0.316 mm the 4th volution, 0.461 mm the 5th volution.initial chamber(proloculus): 88μtunnel angles: 8 degrees in the 1st volution, 17 degrees in the 2nd volution, 20 degrees in the 3rd volution, 15 degrees in the 4th volution, 18 degrees in the 5th volution.
output: The shell is characterized by an ellipsoidal shape with elongated slopes and rounded ends. Its dimensions are as follows: the axial length measures 6.611 mm, while the sagittal width is 3.388 mm, resulting in a length-to-width ratio of 1.951. The shell's axis is straight. The shell exhibits 6.0 volutions, with the tunnels being relatively low and narrow. The thickness of the spirotheca is 0.086 mm. The heights of the first to fifth volutions are 0.142 mm, 0.190 mm, 0.258 mm, 0.316 mm, and 0.461 mm, respectively. The proloculus is small and spherical, with a diameter of 88 μm. The tunnel angles of the first to fifth volutions are 8°, 17°, 20°, 15°, and 18°, respectively. The chomata are well-developed and small in size.
reference: The shell of Pseudoschwagerina needhami is of medium size and inflated fusiform, with a straight axis of coiling, sharply pointed poles, and broadly convex lateral slopes. Mature specimens contain six volutions and are 6.611 mm long and 3.388 mm wide. The form ratio of mature specimens is 1.951. The first volution is ellipsoidal, but beyond the second volution the poles become pointed rather slender through the fourth volution. Beyond this volution the chambers are high and the shell is more robust. Average form ratios of the first to seventh volution in six specimens are 1.6, 1.9, 2.3, 2.6, 2.6, 2.4, and 2.1, respectively.The proloculus is minute, with an outside diameter of 88 μm. The shell expands slowly during the first four volutions, but beyond this the chambers increase in height rapidly. Average height of chambers in the first to seventh volution in six specimens is 50, 75, 120, 180, 320, 411, and 444 microns, respectively. The height of given chambers is about the same from the tunnel to the poles.The spirotheca is thin in the first volution, measuring 10 to 17 microns. However, it increases in thickness gradually, being 78 to 102 microns in the sixth volution. The average thickness of the spirotheca in the first to seventh volution in six specimens is 15, 26, 42, 66, 76, 87, and 85 microns, respectively. Although the spirotheca contains coarse alveoli, its detailed structure cannot be determined in many of my specimens.The septa are thin and contain abundant septal pores. They are closely spaced in the inner three or four volutions but more widely spaced in outer ones. However, the length of chambers in outer volutions is not so great in comparison to shell size as that of most forms referred to this genus. Septal fluting is well defined in the polar areas and extends to the tops of chambers of outermost volutions. However, in tunnel areas, the fluting is confined mainly to the lower parts of chambers. The septal counts of the first to fifth volution of the illustrated sagittal section (fig. 17) are 13, 19, 23, 28, and 26, respectively.The tunnel is narrow in the inner four volutions, increasing in width rapidly beyond the fifth volution. Average tunnel angles in the first to seventh volution of four specimens are 8, 17, 20, 15, 18, 50, and 42 degrees, respectively. The chomata are broad and high in the inner four volutions, and they are narrow and low in the fifth, sixth, and seventh volutions.

Septal fluting is well defined in the polar areas and extends to the tops of chambers of outermost volutions. However, in tunnel areas, the fluting is confined mainly to the lower parts of chambers. Average tunnel angles in the first to seventh volution of four specimens are 24, 13, 27, 13, 30, 5, and 42 degrees, respectively. The chomata are broad and high in the inner four volutions, and they are narrow and low in the fifth, sixth, and seventh volutions.

reference: Thickly ventricose tests of five volutions that commonly reach 6.424 mm in length and 2.783 mm in diameter. In specimens examined, the proloculi range from 109 μm outside diameter. The juvenarium is formed by three closely coiled volutions that are thickly fusiform. In these volutions, the septa are folded into high, rectangular folds and chomata are high, massive, and slightly asymmetrical. The tunnel angle increases from 18 degrees in the first volution to 22 degrees in the fourth volution and then to 45 degrees in the last volution. Secondary deposits commonly coat the septa in the juvenarium but other secondary deposits are lacking.

Thickness of wall in holotype by whorls (in μ): First whorl, 25; second, 35; third, 40; fourth, 80; fifth, 145; and sixth, 130. (The thickness of the wall in specimens from subsurface massifs is greater than in specimens from other regions.) reference: The shell of Pseudoschwagerina rhodesi is small, inflated fusiform in shape, with almost straight axis of coiling, bluntly pointed poles, and uniformly convex lateral slopes. Mature specimens contain 4.5 volutions and are 3.960 mm long and 2.332 mm wide, giving a form ratio of 1.698. The average form ratios of the first to the fourth volution of four specimens are 1.4, 1.8, 2.0, and 2.3, respectively. As shown by the ratios, the polar extension of the shell is greatest in the fourth volution, and form ratios gradually increase to that point. Beyond the fourth volution, the rapid increase in expansion of the shell decreases the value of the form ratio. The first two to three volutions are elliptical in cross-section. The poles of the fourth and fifth volutions are sharply pointed, but those of mature specimens are bluntly pointed.The proloculus is minute, with an outside diameter of 66 microns. The shell expands slowly and gradually during the first three volutions and rapidly beyond the third volution. Outer volutions are highly inflated. The change from low to high chambers takes place through about one complete volution. Average height of chambers in the first to fourth volution in seven specimens is 38, 69, 109, and 240 microns, respectively.The spirotheca is thin throughout the shell, and the alveoli can be seen clearly only in the outer three volutions. Average thickness of the spirotheca of the first to fourth volution in seven specimens is 11.20, 36, 46, and 48 microns, respectively. In many specimens, it is slightly thinner in the fourth volution than in the third but thickens rapidly during the fifth volution.The septa are broadly fluted or irregular throughout their height and length in the outer two to three volutions, but are almost plane in the inner three volutions. In outer volutions, the fluting is only slightly more intense in the polar regions than in the central part of the shell. Septal pores are numerous and relatively coarse. Average septal counts of the first to fifth volution in three specimens are 10, 14, 16, 16, and 17, respectively.Chomata are distinct in the inner five volutions of specimens with six volutions. They are broad in the inner three or four volutions but low and narrow in the fifth volution. The tunnel is low throughout the inner five volutions of mature specimens, becoming broad in the fourth and fifth volutions. Average tunnel angles in the first to third volution in five specimens are 6 degrees, 15, and 23 degrees, respectively.

Average thickness of the spirotheca of the first to fourth volution in seven specimens is 11.20, 36, 46, and 48 microns, respectively. In many specimens, it is slightly thinner in the fourth volution than in the third but thickens rapidly during the fourth volution.The septa are broadly fluted or irregular throughout their height and length in the outer two to three volutions, but are almost plane in the inner three volutions. In outer volutions, the fluting is only slightly more intense in the polar regions than in the central part of the shell. Septal pores are numerous and relatively coarse. Average septal counts of the first to fourth volution in three specimens are 10, 14, 16, and 16, respectively.Chomata are distinct in the inner five volutions of specimens with six volutions. They are broad in the inner three or four volutions but low and narrow in the fourth volution. The tunnel is low throughout the inner five volutions of mature specimens, becoming broad in the fourth and fifth volutions. Average tunnel angles in the first to third volution in five specimens are 5, 8, and 12 degrees, respectively.

output: The shell is characterized by a fusiform shape with concave slopes and rounded ends. reference: Mittelgrosse, subglobusförmige Pseudoschwagerina-Art, welche durch die allmähliche Höhenzunahme und das während des Wachstums fast gleichförmig bleibende Gehäuse gekennzeichnet wird.Gehäuse mittelgross und subglobusförmig, mit ovalen bis halbkugligen Polen. Die ausgewachsenen Exemplare mit 6.5 Windungen messen als Grenzwerte 6.875 mm an Länge und 4.587 mm an Breite. Das Verhältnis der Länge zur Breite ist 1.499 im Umriss und ändert sich sehr langsam beim vorschreitenden Zuwachs folgenderweise: 0.9-1.2, 1.0-1.3, 1.1-1.6, 1.3-1.6, 1.0-1.5, 1.2-1.5, 1.2-1.4 und 1.1-1.4, bzw., vom ersten bis zum sechsten Umgang. Wie es zeigt, so bleibt das Gehäuse fast gleichförmig im Lauf des Wachstums, mit Ausnahme der subsphärischen ersten 2 Umgänge.Anfangskammer nahezu rund und klein; Aussendurchmesser: 594 Mikron als Grenzwerte. Aufrollung wohl eng für die Gattung Pseudoschwagerina. Die ersten 3 oder 4 Umgänge sind fest eingerollt, nehmen aber aussen an Höhe allmählich zu, die folgenden sind etwas locker und der letzte Umgang verengt sich wieder gering. Die Schalenwand ist relativ dünn für die Gattung Pseudoschwagerina, nimmt aber aussen langsam zu; ihre Dicke beträgt an Maximum 0.075.Die Septen stellen sich ziemlich dicht aneinander. Die Septenanzahl steigt von 6-9 im ersten auf 34-38 im sechsten Umgang relativ rasch an. Die Septen sind im jungen Stadium fast flach, aber falten sich im mittleren bis zum alten Stadium entlang der Aufrollungsachse sehr verwirrt. Die kleinen halbrunden Bögen der Septen bilden sich in der Nähe des Tunnels bis zum Pol niedrig.Der Tunnel ist in den fest eingerollten ersten Umgängen sehr eng, andererseits aber in den letzten etwas weit. Die Chomata treten klein halbelliptisch auf in den meisten Umgängen mit Ausnahme des letzten, wo sie nur als Spuren anhalten. Tunnelwinkel betragen 27 Grad im ersten Umgang, 54 Grad im zweiten Umgang, 18 Grad im dritten Umgang, 24 Grad im vierten Umgang, 25 Grad im fünften Umgang und 23 Grad im siebten Umgang.

The shell exhibits 5.0 volutions, with the tunnels being relatively low and narrow. The thickness of the spirotheca is 0.078 mm. reference: Test oval, with convex sides and slightly tapered axial ends. First three or four whorls either spherical or staffelloid, later ones stretch out uniformly. L:D = 1.933. Dimensions small: L = 4.501 mm, D = 2.328 mm. Number of whorls 5.0.Proloculus spherical, very small, thin-walled, 110 μm in diameter. Coil in juvenile stage low, abruptly broadens in fourth or even fifth whorl. Diameter of fourth whorl 0.39-0.75 mm. Wall very thin in initial stage, markedly thickens from fourth whorl; in the last whorls its thickness reaches 130 μm; keriotheca well expressed from the third whorl. Septa thin, with a small amount of irregular fluting only in the region of the axis of coiling of the test. Chomata very small, but distinct, tuberculate, present at the proloculus and in the first three whorls. Aperture very narrow up to the penultimate chamber, where it broadens suddenly. Tunnel low and rather narrow, tunnel angle measuring 7 degrees in the 2nd volution, 7 degrees in the 3rd volution, 14 degrees in the 4th volution, and 5 degrees in the 5th volution.

question: The following is an image of a paleontological fossil, please provide a detailed description for the fossil image. Here is some information about the fossil:length: 8.646 mm. , width(diameter): 3.278 mm. ratio: 2.638number of volutions(whorls): 4.5thickness of spirotheca: 0.069height of volution/whorl: 0.239 mm the 1st volution, 0.400 mm the 2nd volution, 0.572 mm the 3rd volution, 0.397 mm the 4th volution.initial chamber(proloculus): 132μtunnel angles: 5 degrees in the 1st volution, 16 degrees in the 2nd volution, 27 degrees in the 3rd volution.
output: The shell is characterized by an inflated, sub-ellipsoidal shape with elongated slopes and rounded ends. Its dimensions are as follows: the axial length measures 8.646 mm, while the sagittal width is 3.278 mm, resulting in a length-to-width ratio of 2.638. The shell's axis is straight. The shell exhibits 4.5 volutions, with the inner volutions being narrower. The thickness of the spirotheca is 0.069 mm. The heights of the first to fourth volutions are 0.239 mm, 0.400 mm, 0.572 mm, and 0.397 mm, respectively. The proloculus is small and spherical, with a diameter of 132 μm. The tunnel angles of the first to third volutions are 5°, 16°, and 27°, respectively. Additionally, the chomata are well-developed and small in size.
reference: A rather evenly fusiform species of 4.5 volutions, commonly attaining a length of 8.646 mm and a diameter of 3.278 mm. The lateral slopes taper regularly to rather sharp poles. The proloculum is commonly large but shows a wide range of variation as in P. uddeni with extremes of 200 and 400 microns. The juvenarium consists of 2½ to 4 volutions coiled rather closely as in Triticites, the number tending to vary inversely with the size of the proloculum. Following the juvenarium, there is a great increase in the height of the whorls, but the change is not quite so abrupt or so extreme as in P. uddeni. The last volution declines somewhat in height. The antetheca increases in height from the middle to the ends and the ratio of length to diameter as well as the axial profile change only slightly during growth, the ratio being commonly between 2.5 and 3.0 to 1 at maturity. In shells of few rapidly expanding volutions, the measurements vary greatly depending upon the accidental orientation of the axial section with respect to the beginning of the point of inflation, and the measurements and calculated form ratios both show an irregularity that is more apparent than real.The wall is somewhat thicker than in P. uddeni, measuring 0.069 mm in the outer whorls. The septa are rather strongly fluted near their basal margin, but as a result of their wide spacing, opposed folds commonly do not meet. In axial sections, septal loops are abundant or sparse depending on the position of the slice in the chambers. Septalare is abundant in all the inflated whorls.This species displays considerable variation in its proportions and in the distinctness with which its juvenarium is set off by the inflation of the post-nepionic whorls. On the one hand, there are shells relatively shorter and thicker than the types, which grade toward P. uddeni, and on the other hand, there are some that are not easily separated from Schwagerina huecoensis. One of the latter type is here separated as distinct variety, ultima. Apparent differences in proportions are commonly the result of rounding or breaking of the ends as the shells weather free. The inflation takes place within less than half a volution in the average individual but there are occasional shells in which the expansion is more gradual and the generic character is not well marked. It might be supposed that Pseudoschwagerina texana represents the first stage in divergence of this genus from Schwagerina and that actual intergradation at this horizon. On the contrary, it may be argued that this species, in returning to an elongate form, is reducing its inflation and developing a semblance to Schwagerina through convergence. Finally, it might be supposed that this species represents an evolution out of Schwagerina while P. uddeni and other highly inflated species with slightly fluted septa have developed out of it, in which case Pseudoschwagerina is polyphyletic. Of the three alternatives, the second appears most probable. This is not an early or a small species but one of the largest and latest in the Texas section. Its juvenarium has all the features of a prtiticites with well-developed chomata and a fairly thick wall. Moreover, its first inflated whorls are higher than the rest, suggesting a more inflated stage in its ancestry. Dimensions rather large: Length 6.160 mm.; diameter 3.278 mm. Number of whorls six. Initial chamber rather large, 264μ. Spiral tightly coiled in two and one-half to three and one-half whorls. rapidly broadening within the first or first one and one-half whorls of the adult stage, thereafter becoming lower up to the final whorl. Greatest height of the whorls 0.216 mm the 1st volution, 0.239 mm the 2nd volution, 0.099 mm the 3rd volution, 0.342 mm the 4th volution, 0.340 mm the 5th volution.[Wall gradually thickening, reaching 40-50 at the end of the juvenile stage; in the first one and one-half whorls it retains the same thickness or even becomes thinner, and thereafter gradually thickens to 95μ. There is a weakly developed outer tectorium in the first whorls of the juvenile stage.Septa in the juvenile stage rather thick, with intense, high, and narrow folding; in the adult stage the septa are thin and rather intensely folded, forming rather broad, low irregular arches. A dense, finely alveolar network is at the axial ends, Aperture narrow in the juvenile stage, moderately broad, and very low in the following whorls. Septal pores fine, sparse, present in the last two to three whorls. Chomata distinct and high in the juvenile stage; in the adult stage, only the ends of the septa are weakly thickened near the aperture. Tunnel low and rather narrow, tunnel angle measuring 11 degrees in the 2nd volution, 42 degrees in the 3rd volution, 30 degrees in the 4th volution, 30 degrees in the 5th volution.

reference: Mittelgrosse, verlängert ellipsoidale Pseudoschwagerine mit langsamen, gleichmäßigen Zuwachs der Umgänge und der Spirothek. Septen ziemlich stark gefaltet. Die Schalen sind verlängert ellipsoidal mit abgerundeten Polen, mittel-gross; 5.5 Windungen. Einige Exemplare sind 7.040 mm lang und 3.586 mm breit. L/D ist 1.963. Funfeinhalb Windungen. Das Juvenarium besteht aus zweieinhalb bis drei Windungen. Der erste Umgang ist kugelförmig mit bereits betonten Polen, die folgenden zwei sind fusiform, die übrigen ellipsoidal. Die dritte Windung ist relativ am meisten verlängert. Der Unterschied im Zuwachs nach dem dritten Umgang ist beträchtlich, der Übergang rasch, aber nicht sprunghaft. Die Umgänge des erwachsenen Stadiums haben ungefähr die gleiche Breite, nur die letzte Windung ist etwas enger. Im Axialschnitt sieht man, dass die Windungen parallel verlaufen, der Abstand in der Polregion ist ungefähr der gleiche wie an anderen Stellen.Die Spirothek ist mittelmäßig dick und verdickt allmählich. Sie ist ziemlich unruhig, sehr zerbrechlich, zur Bildung von Wülsten und pathologischen Auswüchsen geneigt. Die gewöhnlichste Dicke der Wand der vorletzten Windung beträgt 0.066 mm. Die Antethek ist ziemlich dünn, nur die Septen des Juvenariums sind verhältnismäßig dick. Die Septen sind an den Polen stark gefaltet, aber auch in den äußeren Umgängen am unteren Rand. In der Medianregion hört die Faltung auf. Die Septalporen sind winzig und dicht. Der Tunnel ist eng, von mittlerer Höhe, gegen die äußeren Umgänge wird er immer breiter und niedriger. Die Chomata sind in den ersten drei Umgängen gut entwickelt; sie persistieren - verkümmert und lückenhaft - bis zur letzten Hälfte des Gewindes. Die Embryonalkammer ist regelmäßig, kugelig, mit Eindellungen an der Öffnungsseite. Die Tunnelwinkel betragen 5 Grad in der 1. Windung, 7 Grad in der 2. Windung, 16 Grad in der 3. reference: Auch diese Form konnte ich bloss aus Durchschnitten kennen lernen; doch sind dieselben so trefflich erhalten, dass es hier keine Schwierigkeiten macht, dieselben zu einem Ganzen zu verbinden. Wie schöner Name andeuten soll, so ist dieselbe kurz und gedrungen gebaut. Die Gesammtgestalt derselben ist ausserdem spindelförmig mit mehr oder weniger bauchiger Mitte und gleichmässig zugespitzten Enden, bei einer mittleren Grösse von 5.441 mm.: 2.295 mm. Dass ibrigens auch längere Exemplare vorkommen, welche den Typus aber doch stets sehr wohl erkennen lassen, das ist Etwas, was bei allen ähnlichen Formen immer wiederkehrt. Die einzelnen Kammern sind deutlich und gerundet gewölbt, durch tiefe, Scharf markirte Naths getrennt, verhältnismässig nur wenig nach vorn gezogen. Die Schale zeigte durchschnittlich 4.0 Umgänge und im vierten Umgang 28-30 Kammern. Für die Schalendicke fand ich als mittlere Grössen: -2-2,25,3,3.5,5,6. Hier fällt wohl vor allem wieder die grosse Embryonale, welche in 7,9. dieser Hinsicht verhältnismässig nur geringe Schwankungen zeigt, so wie das rasche Anwachsen der Kammern auf, das noch stärker hervortritt, wenn man die Höhen ihrer Lumina allein untereinander vergleicht. Die Septa sind verhältnismässig dünn, gleichmässig aber fein gefaltet, und zeigen in Durchschnitten, namentlich gegen die Enden zu, ziemlich regelmässige und gedrängte Verbindungen. Die Mindungen lassen sich hier im Allgemeinen an den Achsenschnitten ganz gut unterscheiden und zeigen durchschnittlich eine Höhe = 0.3 des entsprechenden Septums, und eine Breite von 0.003 der jeweiligen Gesammtlänge der Schale. Die Schalenporen sind verhältnismässig ziemlich stark und erreichen nicht selten eine Dicke von bis 0.1 mm, dieselben werden im Allgemeinen durch annähernd gleichgrosse Zwischenräume getrennt. Wenn man nur das Alleräusserste der Gestalt in Betracht ziehen wollte, so könnte man allerdings dazu bewogen werden, unsere Form mit einer ganzen Reihe ähnlicher, besonders amerikanischer Vorkommnisse zusammenzuwerfen: bei einem genaueren Vergleich findet man aber doch zu erhebliche und namentlich zu konstante Unterschiede, als dass dies so ohne Weiteres gerechtfertigt sein könne. Fusulina ventricosa Meek et Haven aus dem Kohlenkalk von Illinois ist es aber, welche hier vor Allem in Betracht zu ziehen wäre, und hatte ich glücklicherweise Gelegenheit, dieselbe in Exemplaren, welche vom Originalfundort stammen, zu untersuchen. So sehr vie Allgemeingestalt bei manchen Exemplaren beider Formen für den ersten Augenblick übereinzustimmen scheint, weil deren kurzer gedrungener Bau vor Allem auffällt, so findet man schon in dieser Hinsicht den konstanten Unterschied, dass unsere Form wohl niemals so hervortretende seitliche Schalenspitzen besitzt, wie sie bei der amerikanischen Art normal zu sein scheinen, sondern dass bei ihr die Verschmalerung zu den ebenfalls abgestumpten seitlichen Enden weit gleichmässiger geschieht. Weit auffälliger wird jedoch der Unterschied, wenn wir uns nicht bloss auf den äusseren Anblick verlassen, sondern auch die inneren Verhältnisse beider genau vergleichen. Ich will zu dem Behuf die Windungshöhen und die fortlaufende Reihe der Schalendicke bei der Form von Illinois hier anführen. reference: Formdes Gehäuses und Oberfläche wie bei der obercarbonischen Form. Auch die Grössenverhältnisse sind die gleichen, wobei jedoch zu bemerken, dass das größte Exemplar über die bei der Hauptform beobachteten Masse hinausging, es hatte eine Länge von 6.974 mm. und eine Höhe von 2.735 mm. Durchmesser ein, bei dem, welcher die weiteste Aufrollung zeigte, dagegen 1.95 mm. Auch der Durchmesser der Anfangskammer unterlag nicht unerheblichen Schwankungen. reference: This species was originally recognized by Schellwien and Dyhrenfurth as a variety of Schellwienia uulğaris with which it is associated in the Darwas region as it is also in North China. As in Schellwienia uulğaris, the present species is also characterized by its remarkably thick spirotheca, relatively thin antethecae and very coarsely alveolar osseum. There is no question as to its intimate relation with Schellwienia uulğaris. For this reason, it seems not unjustifiable to regard it as a variety of that species. After a careful comparison with the typical uulğaris, I find however that there are between them some differentiating features that are at least more marked than those between Schellwtenia uulğariss str. and its other related species, for instance, Schellwienia krotowi. If the latter is to be placed in the rank of a species as Schellwien has done, it appears fair treatment to regard the form under discussion as an independent species as well.Test of this species regularly fusiform up to the fifth volution, then it tends to assume acylindrical shape with its umbilical ends more or less rounded. Axis of the whorls is, as a rule, rectilinear, but occasionally recurved in the median region. Axial length varies from 6 to 7.4 mm and the median width from 1.9 to 2.5 mm, with an average axial ratio of 1:3. Darwas form seems somewhat larger than our representative, though the axial ratio is practically the same.These measurements show that the rate of spiral expansion is much lower than in Schellwienia uulğaris; in other words, the whorls are more compactly coiled. Spirotheca is also slightly thinner than in Schell. uulğaris.Osseum coarsely alveolar, but not quite so coarse as in Schellwienia uulğaris. Antethecae fairly thin, intensely and regularly folded.Buccal aperture broad and comparatively narrow reaching about half the height of the chamber in the first three volutions, and about 2/5 of the height of the chamber from the fourth volution onward. Only a vestige of anuli is observed in the axial section as two small black spots attached to the wall of the initial chamber.Initial chamber spheroidal with an external diameter of 0.3 mm for the macrospheric type, and 0.11 mm for the microspheric. The umbilical ends of the inner volutions often carry a small patch of calcareous deposit.Axial length is 5.562 mm and the median width is 1.939 mm, with an axial ratio of 2.869. Thickness of spirotheca is 0.032. Height of volution/whorl is 0.116 mm for the 1st volution, 0.139 mm for the 2nd volution, 0.174 mm for the 3rd volution, and 0.286 mm for the 4th volution. Initial chamber (proloculus) is 261 μm. Tunnel angles are 17 degrees in the 2nd volution, 20 degrees in the 3rd volution, 14 degrees in the 4th volution, and 6 degrees in the 5th volution.

reference: Das Gehäuse ist subzylindrisch bis verlangert-ellipsoidal; die Poles sind abgerundet, selten etwas ausgezogen. Das ziemlich regelmäßige Gehäuse zeigt keine Biegung der Achse, kein unsymmetrisches Aufrollen, wie dies bei den verwandten Arten vorkommt. Es wurden Exemplare von 6.094 × 2.431 × 2.431 mm gemessen; L/D schwankt demnach zwischen 2.507 und 2.507. Es gibt auch Exemplare von geringerer Breite. Das Minimum beträgt 2.431. Bei normaler Umgangszahl 2.12 mm. Häufig sind fünf Windungen, selten fünf oder sogar vier, doch begegnen wir auch mehr als sechseinhalb Windungen. Der erste Umgang ist kugelig bis ellipsoidal, die übrigen sind kurz zylindrisch. Bei vereinzelten Exemplaren sind die letzten zwei Umgänge mehr verlängert.Die relativ dünne Spirothek wächst allmählich zu und erreicht ihr Maximum gewöhnlich in der vorletzten Windung. Die Rugosität ist bei ihr stark entwickelt, bei allen Individuen gleich; man sieht sie schon vom zweiten Umgang an als winzige Zacken des Tectums, nur selten ist auch die ganze Spirothek krumm. Ich meine, dass die Furchen an der Oberfläche der Spirothek mehr oder weniger senkrecht auf die Achse stehen, weil die geringe Rugosität in den Axialschliffen stärker ausgeprägt erscheint. Die Antitheke ist sehr dünn, dicht perforiert. Obwohl die Septen dünn sind, sehen sie im Medianschnitt oft dick aus, weil sie gebogen, wie sie überall sind, schräg geschnitten werden. Die Septen sind unregelmäßig gefaltet. Das Falten ist sehr schwach im mediären Teil des Gehäuses, was bei den verwandten Arten nicht der Fall ist. Der Tunnel ist breit, schwach und niedrig. Die Chomata sind nur in den inneren Umgängen erhalten. Das Proloculum ist ziemlich groß, selten ganz kugelig, meist in der Richtung der Achse etwas verlängert. Das kleinste misst 0.17 × 0.15, das größte hat den Durchmesser von 0.37 mm.Die Tunnelwinkel betragen 9 Grad in der 2. Windung, 19 Grad in der 3. Windung, 6 Grad in der 4. Windung und 7 Grad in der 5. Windung.

reference: Shell regularly fusiform, hardly changing until the final volution in which the shell becomes subcylindrical with blunted ends. L:D= 3.407, sometimes only 3.0 or up to 4.0. Its dimensions are as follows: axial length is 6.573 mm, sagittal width is 2.292 mm, and the ratio of length to width is approximately 2.868. The shell's axis is straight. The shell exhibits 5.5 volutions, with the following dimensions: the inner volutions are low and narrow, while the outer volutions are broader. The thickness of the spirotheca is 0.054 mm. The height of each volution, measured from the first to the sixth, is 0.176 mm, 0.225 mm, 0.223 mm, 0.182 mm, 0.185 mm, and 0.122 mm, respectively. reference: Test flatly fusiform with rounded, sometimes somewhat curved, poles in the last and next-to-last whorls. Stretching of the test begins early, with the first whorl already having an inflated fusiform shape, and greatly increasing the degree of elongation in the following whorls. Surface covered with frequent but shallow septal grooves. L:D = 2.868. Dimensions average: Length = 6.573 mm, Diameter = 2.292 mm. Number of whorls constant at 5.5. Proloculus spherical or slightly depressed bilaterally, small, 91 μm. Coiling even, diameter of fourth whorl 1.32-1.80 mm. Wall with frequent deep rugosities, of average thickness, thinner in the initial stage than in maturity, where it thickens to 80 μm. Septa form irregular finely alveolar networks at the poles of the test; at the test sides in axial sections rare low triangular and narrow rectangular arches are observed here and there, in the median region the arches are quite rare. Chomata present at proloculus. At the axial ends of the inner whorls there are discontinuous axial fillings. Aperture quite narrow in inner whorls, much broadens in two whorls before the last. Height of aperture about half that of the chamber lumen. Tunnel low and rather narrow, tunnel angle measuring 12 degrees in the 1st volution, 14 degrees in the 2nd volution, 8 degrees in the 3rd volution, 12 degrees in the 5th volution, 11 degrees in the 6th volution.

output: The shell is characterized by an ellipsoidal shape with elongated slopes and rounded ends. Its dimensions are as follows: the axial length measures 0.343 mm, while the sagittal width is 0.298 mm, resulting in a length-to-width ratio of 1.151. The shell's axis is straight. The shell exhibits 5.5 volutions, with the inner volutions featuring narrow tunnels. The thickness of the spirotheca is 0.007 mm. The height of each volution, measured from the first to the fifth, is 0.023 mm, 0.030 mm, 0.021 mm, 0.028 mm, and 0.039 mm, respectively. The proloculus is small and spherical, with a diameter of 44 μm. The tunnel angles of the first to fifth volutions are 6°, 13°, 11°, 9°, and 6°, respectively. reference: Shell minute, short, inflated; with blunt to slightly umbilicate polar ends and convex lateral slopes. Mature shells of 5.5 volutions are 0.343 mm long and 0.298 mm wide, and have a form ratio of 1.151. General shape of shell changes rapidly with growth of individual. Axis of coiling of the first volution short, that of the second volution is about the same as the width of the shell. Form ratios of the first to fifth volutions of the holotype are approximately 0.78, 1.02, 1.20, and vary in subsequent volutions. Axis of coiling of the first volution is at a large angle to that of the fifth volution.Proloculus relatively large. Its outside diameter measures 44μ. Chambers increase in height slowly with growth of shell, averaging 0.023 mm in the first volution, 0.030 mm in the second volution, and 0.021 mm in the third volution. Heights of chambers are not uniform throughout the length of the shell—above measurements were made near the center of the shell.Spirotheca thin, and appears to consist of a single dense layer with a thickness of 0.007 mm. A diaphanotheca or comparable layer cannot be differentiated in the thin spirotheca. It should be pointed out, however, that many specimens of Pseudoschwagerina dallmusi Thompson and Miller associated with this form have carbonate rhombs that replace portions of their spirotheca, indicating that secondary mineralization has altered the fossil forms, at least to some extent. Also, the minute size of S. australis makes it difficult to observe clearly very thin structures of the spirotheca.Septa widely spaced, and their structure resembles that of the spirotheca. Septal counts of the first and second volutions of one specimen are 6 and 12, respectively. Septa plane throughout the length of the shell.Tunnel low and broad. Chomata low and indistinct. Tunnel angle measures 6 degrees in the first volution, 13 degrees in the second volution, 11 degrees in the third volution, 9 degrees in the fourth volution, and 6 degrees in the fifth volution.

output: The shell is characterized by an ellipsoidal shape with elongated slopes and rounded ends. Its dimensions are as follows: the axial length measures 7.007 mm, while the sagittal width is 3.553 mm, resulting in a length-to-width ratio of 1.972. The shell's axis is straight. The shell exhibits 7.0 volutions, with the inner volutions featuring narrow tunnels. The thickness of the spirotheca is 0.065 mm. The height of the first to seventh volutions is 0.136 mm, 0.200 mm, 0.288 mm, 0.299 mm, 0.253 mm, and 0.211 mm, respectively. The proloculus is small and spherical, with a diameter of 329 μm. The tunnel angles of the first to seventh volutions are 14°, 6°, 15°, 7°, 18°, and 7°, respectively. The chomata are well-developed and small in size.
reference: Shell large, inflated fusiform, with sharply-pointed poles, steep slightly concave lateral slopes, and straight axis of coiling. Mature specimens of 7.0 volutions measure 7.007 mm in length and 3.553 mm in width, giving a form ratio of 1.972. The shell retains essentially the same shape throughout growth of the individual. The form ratio is about 1:2 for the first volution to maturity. However, the lateral slopes of the first three to four volutions are convex, but the lateral slopes of the outer volutions of mature specimens become slightly concave.The proloculum is large and spherical in shape. Its outside diameter measures 329 μm. The shell expands essentially uniformly up to about the fifth volution. In the holotype, the chambers increase in height up to the fifth volution, but they decrease in height slightly from the fifth volution to maturity. In several other specimens, however, the chambers increase in height slightly from the fifth volution to maturity. The average heights of the chambers in the first to the seventh volution of three specimens are 0.136 mm, 0.200 mm, 0.288 mm, 0.299 mm, 0.253 mm, 0.211 mm, and 0.253 mm, respectively.The septa are relatively thick. They are distinctly pendant-shaped in cross-section, but the lower margins of the septa are distinctly thicker immediately over the tunnel than poleward from the tunnel. Although the anterior thin dark layer of the septa seems to be continuous with the tectum of the spirotheca, the posterior wedge-shaped layer occurs between the alveoli of the keriotheca of the spirotheca and the anterior thin dark layer of the septa. The septa are narrowly fluted throughout the length of the shell. However, further than the presence of these poorly developed cuneculi, this species has little resemblance to the genotype of Parafusulina, p. wordensis Dunbar and Skinner. The average septal counts of the first to the seventh volution of two specimens are 12, 18, 27, 32, 34, 30, and 30, respectively.The spirotheca is thick and composed of a tectum and keriotheca with coarse alveoli. In fact, the keriotheca has coarse alveoli in the first part of the first volution. Secondary deposits continuous with the chomata and axial fillings cover the upper surfaces of the spirotheca in most parts of the inner volutions, but thin sections of numerous specimens indicate that the porous structure of the keriotheca completely penetrates the spirotheca in the outer volutions. The average thicknesses of the spirotheca in the first to the seventh volution of four specimens measure about 50, 70, 90, 110, 150, 150, and 150 microns, respectively.The tunnel is low and of medium width, and its path is straight. The average tunnel angles of the second to the sixth volutions of two specimens measure 14°, 6°, 15°, 7°, 18°, and 7°, respectively. Discontinuous irregular chomata border the tunnel in the second volution to the beginning part of the last volution. Dense calcite essentially fills the chambers in the polar regions of the second to the next to outermost volution.

reference: Form des Gehäuses: sehr gestreckt spindelförmig, polwärts stark zugespitzt. Grösse: sehr gering. Umgangszahl: 5.5. Wanddicke: sehr gering. Wabenwerk: schwer erkennbar, sehr kurz und eng. Fältelung: nur entlang der achse vorhanden, sehr gering. Medialreifen: relativ wohl ausgebildet, regelmässig, infolge der geringen Fältelung sehr deutlich.Eine bisher nur in Iowa sicher nachgewiesene Form teilt eine Anzahl Eigentümlichkeiten mit Fus. centralis var. irregularis, zeichnet sich jedoch durch eine ganz besondere Kleinheit aus. Bei einer Achsenlänge von 4.895 mm und einer Sagittalhöhe von 1.474 mm erreicht diese Fusuline reichliche 5.5 Umgänge. Medialreifen, besw. keulige Verdickung des Septenuntersaumes zu beiden Seiten der Mundspalte, die Dünne der Wand, die Kleinheit, die Feinwabigkeit nähern diese Form dem Typus der Fus. obsoleta (sowie einer noch nicht abgebildeten Fusuline Spitzbergens) so sehr, dass eine Gruppenvereinigung trotz der höheren Zahl der niedrigeren Umgänge fast erlaubt erscheinen könnte. Doch liegt bei der Fus. obsoleta, wie schon Schellwien hervorhob, die Annahme nahe, dass es sich nur um eine degenerierte Brackwasserform der Gruppe der Fus. simplex handelt. Bei den nahen Beziehungen der Gruppen der Fus. simplex und der Fus. secalis, die sich in der Neigung zu geringer Fältelung, der Septenzahl, der Tendenz zur Bildung von Medialreifen etc. ausspricht, ist die Möglichkeit, dass wir in der vorliegenden Form nur eine den gleichen Verhältnissen des Brackwassers angepasste Konvergenzform zu Fus. obsoleta zu erblicken haben viel zu gross, als dass aus Gründen der Systematik eine Gruppenvereinigung statthaft sein dürfte.Auch zu Fus. bocki sind morphologische Beziehungen vorhanden. Doch dürfte letztere Spezies biphylet sein, indem der eine Teil der von Schellwien ihr zugezählten Formen mir vielleicht mehr zu der Gruppe der Mus. pusilla zu gehören scheint.Proloculus klein, dessen äussere Durchmesser 66μ beträgt. Der Tunnel ist niedrig und eher schmal, wobei der Tunnelwinkel im 2. Umgang 24 Grad, im 3. Umgang 10 Grad und im 4. Umgang 14 Grad misst.

output: The shell is characterized by an inflated, sub-ellipsoidal shape with elongated slopes and rounded ends. Its dimensions are as follows: the axial length measures 2.508 mm, while the sagittal width is 0.968 mm, resulting in a length-to-width ratio of 2.591. The shell's axis is straight. The shell exhibits 5.0 volutions, with the tunnels being relatively low and narrow. The thickness of the spirotheca is 0.018 mm. The heights of the first to fifth volutions are 0.038 mm, 0.049 mm, 0.107 mm, and 0.184 mm, respectively. The proloculus is small and spherical, with a diameter of 54 μm. The tunnel angles of the third and fourth volutions are 13° and 7°, respectively. Additionally, the chomata are well-developed and small in size.
reference: Test fusiform, diameter ratio 2.591, number of whorls 5.0. Coiling tighter in early whorls and rapidly expanding in outer whorls. Wall has a diaphanotheca up to the last whorl; from the fourth or fifth whorl pores are noted. Wall thickness 0.018 mm. Chomata in height up to half the chamber lumen, asymmetrical in the early whorls and rounded-rectangular in the outer whorls. Tunnel angle 13° in the 3rd volution and 7° in the 4th volution.Test fusiform, with an inflated median region. Slightly convex in the last whorl, sometimes with almost straight sides and narrowly rounded, more rarely acute ends; in the early whorls the shape of the test is approximately ovoid. On the surface there are quite deep septal grooves. Length: diameter ratio 2.591, individually 2.8, sometimes 2.4. In the fourth whorl the length: diameter ratio is 2.1-2.4. Number of whorls 5.0.Proloculus small, spherical, with an outside diameter of 54 μm. Coiling tighter in early whorls, then quite rapidly expanding.Wall consists of a thin tectum, a quite broad faint diaphanotheca, an inner tectorium which varies greatly in width (width in a single specimen varies from a fourth to two-thirds of the total wall thickness), and a narrow, not always present outer tentorium. Sometimes, starting from the fourth or fifth whorl, fine pores, barely noticeable as such, are observed in the wall, which also penetrate the chomata; in one case in the last whorl in the inner tectorium a lighter band was present, a kind of secondary diaphanotheca. Wall thickness in last whorls 0.018 mm. Septa thinner than wall, straight in median region and slightly fluted at axial ends where they form an irregular coarsely alveolar network. Chomata in second, and sometimes also in the third whorl weak, asymmetrical, with a very gently sloping outside edge; in later whorls they become higher, assuming a rounded-rectangular shape: the height of the chomata in the early whorls, as a rule, is less than half the height of the chamber lumen, in the later whorls about half or somewhat more. In the chomata are observed layering and sometimes a slightly noticeable fine porosity from the fourth whorl on. Aperture quite rapidly broadens in outer whorls, with an irregular position, in height less than half the height of the chamber lumen: tunnel angle 13° in the 3rd volution and 7° in the 4th volution.

output: The shell is characterized by an ellipsoidal shape with elongated slopes and rounded ends. Its dimensions are as follows: the axial length measures 3.630 mm, while the sagittal width is 2.090 mm, resulting in a length-to-width ratio of 1.737. The shell's axis is straight. The shell exhibits 4.5 volutions, with the inner volutions being narrower. The thickness of the spirotheca is 0.036 mm. The height of each volution is as follows: 0.153 mm for the first, 0.164 mm for the second, 0.291 mm for the third, and 0.283 mm for the fourth. The chomata are well-developed and small in size.
reference: Shell small, attaining lengths of 3.630 mm and widths of 2.090 mm in 4.5 volutions. The shape is fusiform with irregular to concave lateral slopes and bluntly pointed poles. The coiling is relatively loose and the chambers relatively open with little secondary filling and small chomata.The spiral form is normal to normal negative increasing regularly through the early volutions and increasing only slightly less in the outer volutions. The pattern for the increase in height of volution shows that the increase is quite regular throughout most of the growth. The height of the 1st volution is 0.153 mm, the 2nd volution is 0.164 mm, the 3rd volution is 0.291 mm, and the 4th volution is 0.283 mm.The length increases logarithmically in relation to the diameter. The spread is narrow throughout, indicating a close homogeneity in specimens from the seven samples. The form ratio increases rapidly in the early stages of growth and then remains almost constant at 1.737.The shape is fusiform throughout, with a tendency to develop concave lateral slopes even in some of the early volutions. The proloculus ranges in outer diameter from 50 to 130 microns in the megalospheric specimens. More than a third of the specimens are in the 75 to 90 micron range, and the rest fall about equally to each side of this central cluster. Several microspheric juvenaria were found with proloculi approximately 25 microns in diameter. Some specimens with larger proloculi seem intermediate in form with the initial chambers at an angle to the adult chambers.The wall thickness increases regularly, with the maximum thickness recorded being 32 microns. The wall has a tectum and well-defined diaphanotheca and thin, irregular tectoria, mostly in the vicinity of the septa.The septa tend to be plane or slightly fluted and are spaced rather regularly throughout most of the shell. The septal spacing increases arithmetically with increasing radius. The septa are thickened to wedges or bulbs by secondary deposits in the vicinity of the tunnel and chomata. The tunnel is well defined by the chomata. It is generally low, extending less than half the height of the chambers. It tends to be straight or only slightly irregular and increases rapidly in width. The bounding chomata are small and tend to be symmetrical. The tunnel angle measures 7 degrees in the 1st volution, 5 degrees in the 2nd volution, 8 degrees in the 3rd volution, and 9 degrees in the 4th volution. Where the plane of the septa coincides or nearly coincides with the plane at the section, the chomata appear to be more massive and asymmetrical because of the extensions of secondary deposits along the septa.
