output: The shell is characterized by an ellipsoidal shape with elongated slopes and rounded ends. Its dimensions are as follows: the axial length measures 5.291 mm, while the sagittal width is 2.882 mm, resulting in a length-to-width ratio of 1.836. The shell's axis is straight. The shell exhibits 8.0 volutions, with the inner volutions featuring narrow tunnels. The thickness of the spirotheca is 0.045 mm. The heights of the first to eighth volutions are 0.091 mm, 0.143 mm, 0.159 mm, 0.161 mm, 0.172 mm, 0.246 mm, and 0.268 mm, respectively. The proloculus is small and spherical, with a diameter of 109 μm. The tunnel angles of the second to seventh volutions are 5°, 13°, 7°, 14°, and 15°, respectively. The chomata are well-developed and small in size.
reference: Similar to F. girtyi but more slender and elongate. The middle is inflated, the poles extended, and the lateral slopes distinctly concave. The average length of seven measured specimens is 5.291 mm and the diameter is 2.882 mm, but fully grown shells having 8 volutions attain a length of about 5.291 mm and a diameter of 2.882 mm, the form ratio being 1.836 in this species (occasional shells are still larger and have as many as 9 volutions). The adult proportions are attained at an early stage and the changes during growth are small and irregular.The proloculus ranges in diameter from about 109 μm. The spiral wall is very thin, as in F. girtyi, and epicuticular deposits are similarly disposed but lighter than in that species. Thus, instead of forming heavy chomata in the form of levee-like ridges on the floor of the volutions, the deposit is laid down on the septa and roof as well as the floor, constricting or even filling the chambers for a short distance on each side of the tunnel, and even thickening the septa where they hang pendant above the tunnel.The septa are rather closely spaced and are regularly and strongly fluted with high, narrow folds. Strong septal plication began at an early stage of growth and the fusulinelloid stage, if recognizable at all, is restricted to the first volution in shells with large prolocula or the first two in those with small prolocula.The tunnel is generally wider, averaging between 20° and 25° instead of 15°, but the ranges in the two species overlap considerably. In this species, the tunnel angle is widest in the early volutions. Specifically, the tunnel angles are 5 degrees in the 2nd volution, 13 degrees in the 4th volution, 7 degrees in the 5th volution, 14 degrees in the 6th volution, and 15 degrees in the 7th volution.These three forms occur together in the Brereton limestone and apparently are genetically related. In a locality such as station B9, where thousands of specimens can be freed from a calcareous shale, the majority can be separated on shape alone into three groups here recognized. Yet individual variation is great enough so that the three groups overlap in form and perhaps one-fourth of the specimens appear to be transitional. Whether the three groups are specific or varietal is problematical. It seems unlikely that these variations are merely individual because in some parts of the State not all forms are present and, moreover, neither form is restricted to any particular lithology so far as the junior author's somewhat limited observations indicate. At certain localities, but not everywhere, in Randolph County, occurs almost alone. We recognize these three closely allied forms as distinct species rather than varieties chiefly for the advantage of simplicity in nomenclature.Occasional specimens, as figures 4 and 5 on plate 13, show abnormally massive epicuticular deposits near the tunnel.

output: The shell is characterized by an inflated, sub-ellipsoidal shape with elongated slopes and rounded ends. Its dimensions are as follows: axial length is 5.525 mm, sagittal width is 1.963 mm, and the ratio of length to width is approximately 2.815. The shell's axis is straight. The shell exhibits 5.5 volutions, with the inner volutions being narrower. The thickness of the spirotheca is 0.036 mm. The height of each volution, measured from the first to the fifth, is 0.118 mm, 0.130 mm, 0.180 mm, 0.234 mm, and 0.213 mm, respectively. The proloculus is small and spherical, with a diameter of 186 μm. The tunnels are low and narrow, with an angle of 12 degrees between the third and fourth volutions. The chomata are well-developed and small in size.
reference: Shell elongated-fusiform, slightly inflated medially with gradually narrowing and obtusely pointed ends. Shell quite appreciably elongated already beginning from the second volution. Ratio L:D in third volution equal to 2.5-3.0, in the outer volutions the ratio varies from 2.9 to 4.17. Shell of medium size: L = 5.525 mm., D = 1.963 mm.; number of volutions 5.5, more often 6. Initial chamber 186μ. Whorls coiling very uniformly. Diameter of fourth volution measuring 0.7-1.13 mm.; more frequently occurs form with diameter equal to 0.9-1.0 mm. Theca with a distinct diaphanotheca, moderately thick. In the outer whorls it attains a thickness of 35-45μ, in the inner ones 25-35μ.Septa fairly thick, somewhat thinner than the theca, quite strongly folded. Folds forming regular, not thickly set loops, fairly lofty, rounded and occasionally subsquare in shape, not traceable along the axis in the inner volutions because of the massive and compact axial zone.Aperture regularly situated, of medium height, narrow in the inner volutions, gradually expanding in the outer ones. Chomata distinct on 4-5 whorls; axial part considerably compact; axial zone well developed on 4-5 whorls.From the latter our species differs by compact axial part and elongated form of shell through all the whorls. To Fusulina pancouensts (Lee), the form under discussion comes near in the structure of the theca, elongated form of the shell and presence of compact axial part, while differing from it in the form of the spiral and more regular folding: Analysis of material on hand warrants the assumption that Fusulina pancouensis and Pusulina innae Rozovskaya are genetically closely interrelated. These two species manifest quite vividly that there are certain regularities underlying the development of individual characters which have served as a basis for Rauser-Chernoussova to trace the phylogeny of the whole fusulinid family.Pusulina innae makes its appearance in the lower half of the Podolsk horizon and undergoes further development throughout its entire range. In the upper half of this horizon this form yields a side-branch—Fusulina pancouensis, evidently expiring here because of peculiar specialization of its characters. These characters are: strongly elongated shell along the axis of coiling already in the most youthful whorls, intense septal folding and axial part compact and strongly developed. Tunnel low and rather narrow, tunnel angle measuring 12 degrees in the 3rd volution.

reference: Test short, fusiform, with a strongly convex median region, and rounded ends. Ratio of length to diameter (in the holotype) is 2.135:1. Septa are not constant in thickness, and are often quite thick with high, angular and irregular plications. The plications are irregularly distributed, sometimes beginning near the aperture. There are small distinct chomata only in the first two whorls, and only pseudochomata in the following whorls. Aperture very narrow until the penultimate whorl, where it broadens to a moderate width. The position of the aperture is very irregular. reference: Test large, subcylindrical or highly elongate fusiform, with pointed axial ends. Ratio of length to diameter 3.406. question: The following is an image of a paleontological fossil, please provide a detailed description for the fossil image. Here is some information about the fossil:length: 2.585 mm. , width(diameter): 0.940 mm. ratio: 2.749number of volutions(whorls): 5.5thickness of spirotheca: 0.014height of volution/whorl: 0.063 mm the 1st volution, 0.068 mm the 2nd volution, 0.085 mm the 3rd volution, 0.110 mm the 4th volution, 0.112 mm the 5th volution.initial chamber(proloculus): 66μtunnel angles: 5 degrees in the 2nd volution, 11 degrees in the 3rd volution, 7 degrees in the 4th volution.
output: The shell is characterized by an inflated, sub-ellipsoidal shape with elongated slopes and rounded ends. Its dimensions are as follows: the axial length measures 2.585 mm, while the sagittal width is 0.940 mm, resulting in a length-to-width ratio of 2.749. The shell's axis is straight. The shell exhibits 5.5 volutions, with the inner volutions featuring narrow tunnels. The thickness of the spirotheca is 0.014 mm. The heights of the first to fifth volutions are 0.063 mm, 0.068 mm, 0.085 mm, 0.110 mm, and 0.112 mm, respectively. The proloculus is small and spherical, with a diameter of 66 μm. The tunnel angles of the second to fourth volutions are 5°, 11°, and 7°, respectively. Additionally, the chomata are well-developed and small in size.
reference: Shell small, uniformly fusiform, slightly elongate, with rather sharply pointed poles, with straight axis of coiling, and with shallow external furrows. Nature specimens of 5.5 volutions are 2.585 mm in length and 0.940 mm in width. The rate of increase in size is rather uniform throughout the length of the shell but there is a uniform decrease of form ratio in the third volution the form ratio is 1:1.9, in the fourth volution 1:2.2, in the fifth volution 1:2.4, in the sixth volution 1:2.6, and in mature specimens 1:2.8. The septa are relatively thin and are composed of four layers. The two outer layers are thicker in the lower part of the septa where they fuse adjacent septa for about two-thirds the height of the chambers at the points of approach caused by the fluting. The posterior portion of the anterior tectorium is somewhat lighter than the remaining portion but it does not seem to join structurally with the diaphanotheca of the following chamber. The external furrows have an irregular course across the mid-portion of the shell but they are somewhat sinuous in the region of the poles. The septa are very highly fluted throughout the length of the shell and the fluting extends to the top of the septa; however, it is less pronounced in the upper one-third of the chamber. Tangential sections show the flutings to form short elliptical openings or chamberlets; these are located in the lower portion of the chambers and they are about two-thirds as high as the chambers. The septal count for the earlier volutions of the shell is about 17 in the second volution, 19 in the third volution, 24 in the fourth volution, and 28 in the fifth volution. In some specimens the septal count varies as much as four in the fourth volution and three in the fifth volution. The proloculum is sub-spherical to spherical and has a diameter of 66 μm. The ontogenetic development of individuals is divisible into an early state (a "juvenarium") during which the inner two and one-half volutions are tightly coiled and a later stage during which the outer volutions are less tightly coiled. The spirotheca or wall is relatively thick. The upper tectorium is about 6.0 μm thick in the sixth volution and is composed of rather dense material which is slightly less dense near its lower surface. The diaphanotheca measures 5.9 μm in the sixth volution. The lower tectorium is about 11.7 μm thick over the tunnel in the sixth volution but it thins rapidly toward the poles and is absent in the last volution. The upper tectorium is present on the floors of all chambers but it is not found on the spirotheca of the last volution. The difference in density between the diaphanotheca and the lower part of the upper tectorium is very slight and the line of division would be very difficult to locate if it were not for the presence of the tectum. The tunnel is rather low and broad and it is about one-third as high as the chamber and about one-fourth as high as wide. The average tunnel angle is about 5 degrees in the 2nd volution, 11 degrees in the 3rd volution, and 7 degrees in the 4th volution. The floor of the tunnel is covered by a thick layer of tectorium, and either side of the tunnel is bordered by a very high and broadly rounded, more or less symmetrical ridge, the choma, which, in the fifth and sixth volutions, is about two-thirds as high as the chambers and is about as broad at the top as it is high—it is only slightly developed in the outer volution. Two groups of specimens are included under this species which are somewhat doubtfully conspecific but which present certain similarities. The above description is based almost entirely on the first group of these specimens which is represented by figures 2, 5, 8, 14, and 20 on plate 21, they differ from the second group of specimens represented by figures 1, 4, 12, 13, 15, and 19 on plate 21 particularly in that the septa are more narrowly fluted, the shells are larger, and the form ratios for corresponding volutions are larger.

reference: Test elongate fusiform, with a convex median region, flat sides, and bluntly pointed axial ends. Ratio of length to diameter 2.518. Inner whorls subrhomboidal in section, rather short, elongation of the test taking place rapidly in the last two whorls. Dimensions moderate: Length 3.767 mm; diameter 1.496 mm. Number of whorls four and one-half. Initial chamber with a diameter of 66μ. Spire moderately tightly coiled in the first three whorls and rather loosely coiled in the succeeding ones. Wall thin, from a5u to 3ou, with a distinctly defined diaphanotheca in some places. Septa thin, rather strongly folded throughout the length of the test. Septal arches usually not constant in form, ranging from high to low and wide. In the majority of the specimens the chomata are distinctly defined, usually not constant in form and height, present up to the penultimate whorl. In the axial regions of the whorls, weak and intermittent supplementary deposits are observed, but in some specimens they are absent. Aperture narrow, of moderate height in the early whorls, later expanding uniformly to rather broad.Tunnel low and rather narrow, tunnel angle measuring 7 degrees in the 1st volution, 13 degrees in the 3rd volution, 6 degrees in the 4th volution, and 17 degrees in the 6th volution.
